greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n with product of multiplicities of parts equal to n.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
example: a(8) = 2 because among the 22 (= A000041(8)) partitions of 8 only [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1] and [1,1,1,1,2,2] have product of multiplicities of parts equal to 8.
maple: b:= proc(n, i, p) option remember; `if`(p=1 and i*(i+1)/2<n, 0,
mathematica: b[n_, i_, p_] := b[n, i, p] = If[p == 1 && i*(i + 1)/2 < n, 0, If[n == 0, If[p == 1, 1, 0], If[i < 1, 0, b[n, i - 1, p] + Sum[If[Mod[p, j] == 0, b[n - i*j, i - 1, p/j], 0], {j, 1, Min[p, n/i]}]]]]; a[n_] := If[PrimeQ[n], 1, b[n, n, n]]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 70}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 22 2016, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_ and _Alois P. Heinz_, Dec 30 2015
